answers.author: Silas Clarke
answers.text:
As a new City Administrator (6 months) of a smaller town, my biggest advice is to: 1) meet your employees and shake their hand as early as possible; 2) keep your ears open at all times to pick up on culture of the organization; and, 3) meet the community naysayers (They will be in, just listen during your first meeting).  Good luck, Silas

One of the things I did going in was make a list of everyone I wanted to sit down with and meet and then use that as your guide. As projects and tasks mount it is easy to deviate from following through on meeting with everyone.

answers.author: Kenneth Decker
answers.text:
Identify people in the community you need to meet and take them to lunch.  Talk about things other than "work" and listen far more than you talk.  Ask questions about the community.  Listen to people's personal stories.  Show a genuine interest.  Always pick up the tab... and pay for it yourself.  People will notice and it will be one of the best investments you make.

author: Frank Lancaster
text:
I'm going to be taking a new position as a Town Manager in about a month.  I'm leaving a county manager position I've held for about 18 years, so I haven't started with a new organization for quite some time.   I'm also moving from a large organization (1500 employees) to a smaller one (150 employees)  I'd really appreciate any advice anyone has for what do you do when you first walk into an organization as the new manager.   Any tips of what to do?  What not to do?  What should be my plan for the first few weeks, or few months to help insure getting off on the right foot. 
thanks,
Frank Lancaster
Larimer County, Co County manager/ soon to be Town of Estes Park, CO Town Administrator.
title: Advice for the first few weeks as a new manager
